content.text:
This two-year-old boy was brought to CHP with 3-week history of occipital headaches. The mother tells you he sleeps with his neck extended. During the last week prior to presenting to CHP he vomited once/day. On neurologic exam there was no noticeable weakness, gait abnormality, balance or visual changes. The mass lesion is partially resected. Your diagnosis? <image 1> <image 2>

A. Pilocytic astrocytoma
B. Subependymoma
C. Glioblastoma
D. Anaplastic ependymoma
E. Medulloblastoma

The images provided are MRI scans of the brain, showing a mass lesion in the posterior fossa. Given the clinical presentation of a 2-year-old boy with occipital headaches, vomiting, and the location of the mass, the most likely diagnosis is:

E. Medulloblastoma

Medulloblastomas are common pediatric brain tumors that typically arise in the cerebellum and can present with symptoms such as headaches and vomiting due to increased intracranial pressure. The age of the patient and the location of the tumor on the MRI are consistent with this diagnosis.
Now, output the final answer and nothing else:
